The builders of the Empire State Building faced numerous obstacles in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock at the building. One major obstacle was the safety concern associated with the use of hydrogen in dirigibles, which was highly flammable. This concern became evident after the Hindenburg disaster in 1937, which highlighted the potential dangers of a hydrogen-filled dirigible above a densely populated area like downtown New York. As a result, using the mooring mast for docking dirigibles became a safety issue.

Another obstacle was the unpredictable winds on top of the Empire State Building caused by violent air currents. The winds constantly shifted, leading to the swiveling of the dirigible around the mooring mast. This created instability and safety risks, as dirigibles moored in open landing fields could be weighted down in the back with lead weights to counteract the wind. However, using such weights high above pedestrians on the street was deemed impractical and unsafe.

Additionally, an existing law prohibited airships from flying too low over urban areas, making it illegal for dirigibles to tie up to the Empire State Building or even approach the area. Despite two attempts by dirigibles, including the U.S. Navy dirigible Los Angeles and the Goodyear blimp Columbia, to dock at the building, these legal restrictions prevented their successful mooring.

The feasibility of mooring airships to a fixed mast at such a height also posed unsolved technical problems, contributing to the obstacles faced by the builders. These challenges were significant enough that the final installation of the landing gear was postponed and eventually abandoned. By the late 1930s, the idea of using the mooring mast for dirigibles had been quietly abandoned as airplanes became the preferred mode of transportation.

In conclusion, the builders of the Empire State Building encountered obstacles such as safety concerns related to hydrogen-filled dirigibles, unpredictable winds, legal restrictions on low-flying airships over urban areas, and technical challenges in mooring airships at such height. These obstacles ultimately prevented the successful docking of dirigibles at the Empire State Building, leading to the abandonment of the mooring mast idea.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It's not that a group of old guys doesn't know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place. Things change. At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn't have done was let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park. They'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn't cool down. It didn't matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so cruel. I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my sirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I'd be fine.Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch's Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head. That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain. I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. With any luck I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time. Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me. GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE'RE YOUR BEST BET! And the only bet,” I remember thinking. As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even though I didn't own a rod or reel. An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. “Where you headed in such a hurry?” “Yosemite,” I whispered. “Know the best way to get there?” I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group I'd listened to in Lodi. “Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” And I promised myself right then that I'd always stick to it in the future. Now write a response that explains how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. In your response, include examples from the essay that support your conclusion.

message.content:
In the essay, the features of the setting play a significant role in influencing the cyclist's experience. The setting, which includes the terrain, weather, and availability of resources, ultimately affects the cyclist's physical and mental state.

Firstly, the terrain of the setting directly impacts the cyclist's journey. In the beginning, the cyclist is optimistic and enjoys the serenity of an early-summer evening. However, as the journey progresses, the terrain becomes challenging and unforgiving. The flat road transforms into short, rolling hills, and eventually, a rough road warns against exceeding the speed limit. These physical obstacles drain the cyclist's energy and exacerbate the difficulties they face.

Additionally, the scarcity of necessary resources such as water amplifies the challenges faced by the cyclist. The old men's incorrect advice regarding the availability of towns leads the cyclist to rely on his water supply, which proves to be inadequate. As a result, the cyclist becomes dehydrated and desperate for water as he encounters non-functional water pumps and a lack of inhabited areas. The absence of water exacerbates the physical toll on the cyclist, increasing the risk of heatstroke and compromising their well-being.

Furthermore, the desolate and abandoned surroundings have a psychological impact on the cyclist. The cyclist describes the once-thriving town turned into a ghost town as well as the abandoned Welch's Grape Juice factory. These desolate and hopeless sights contribute to the cyclist's feelings of despair and hopelessness. The lack of human presence and signs of life intensify the cyclist's isolation and vulnerability on their journey.

Overall, the features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist's physical and mental well-being. The challenging terrain, lack of necessary resources, and desolate surroundings all contribute to the cyclist's struggles and their sense of vulnerability. These elements highlight the importance of considering the setting when embarking on a journey, emphasizing the need to gather accurate information and prepare adequately to navigate through challenging environments.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

message.content:
Once upon a time in a small village nestled amidst rolling hills, there lived a young girl named Maya. She possessed an unwavering spirit and a heart full of empathy, constantly striving to understand the world around her. Maya's greatest quality, however, was her extraordinary patience, which she displayed in the face of every challenge that came her way.

In her village, people often sought Maya's guidance whenever they encountered difficulties. One day, a farmer named Mr. Patel approached her with a weary expression on his face. His crops had been worn thin by drought, testing the strength of his resolve.

Having learned about patience from her humble grandparents, Maya listened attentively to Mr. Patel's plight. Aware that expressing his frustrations could bring some solace, she keenly lent her ear. As he poured out his worries, Maya's understanding and tolerance filled the space between them, soothing his troubled heart.

With compassion radiating from her kind eyes, Maya offered Mr. Patel a different perspective on his struggle. She spoke of the resilience of nature, reminding him that after every storm, the sun eventually emerges. Encouraged by her gentle words, Mr. Patel found a renewed sense of determination within himself.

As the days turned into weeks, Maya continued to support Mr. Patel with her patient presence. She observed as he toiled tirelessly, caring for his crops and nurturing them with unwavering dedication. Despite witnessing meager signs of growth, Maya remained confident that perseverance would lead them to a bountiful harvest.

In time, Maya's unwavering belief bore fruit, quite literally. One early morning, as golden rays pierced the horizon, the village awakened to a breathtaking sight. Mr. Patel's once-weary fields were now transformed into a vibrant sea of green, filled with robust crops stretching towards the sky. Joy and gratitude filled the village, akin to the hope that had been revived within Mr. Patel's heart.

Maya's quiet patience and steadfast support had not only uplifted Mr. Patel but had also inspired the entire community. Her actions demonstrated the power of empathy and understanding, reminding them all to face challenges with resilience and an unwavering belief in a brighter future.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It's not that a group of old guys doesn't know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place. Things change. At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn't have done was let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park. They'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn't cool down. It didn't matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so cruel. I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my sirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I'd be fine.Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch's Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head. That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain. I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. With any luck I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time. Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me. GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE'RE YOUR BEST BET! And the only bet,” I remember thinking. As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even though I didn't own a rod or reel. An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. “Where you headed in such a hurry?” “Yosemite,” I whispered. “Know the best way to get there?” I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group I'd listened to in Lodi. “Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” And I promised myself right then that I'd always stick to it in the future. message.content:
In the given essay, the features of the setting play a significant role in affecting the cyclist both physically and mentally. The setting, comprised of the deserted and barren landscapes of California, creates challenges for the cyclist and influences their decision-making. The changing terrain, lack of water sources, and abandoned buildings contribute to the cyclist's plight.

Firstly, the changing terrain impacts the cyclist's journey. Initially, the cyclist embarks on the ride with strong legs and a smile, expecting a smooth and enjoyable ride towards Yosemite National Park. However, as the cyclist progresses, the road transitions from flat to rolling hills, making the journey more physically demanding. The cyclist must exert more effort and energy, adding to their fatigue and dehydration.

Additionally, the scarcity of water sources in the high deserts of California intensifies the cyclist's struggle. The essay describes how the old guys' advice leads the cyclist to a pump that only spews brackish water, unsuitable for consumption. This forces the cyclist to conserve their limited water supply and push themselves further without adequate hydration. The lack of water exacerbates the cyclist's dehydration and heatstroke risk.

Furthermore, the presence of abandoned buildings and ghost towns adds to the cyclist's difficulties. The essay depicts the cyclist coming across a ghost town and an abandoned Welch's Grape Juice factory. These encounters highlight the desolation of the setting and emphasize the cyclist's isolation and vulnerability. The cyclist begins to lose hope as they realize the dire predicament they are in, with no immediate support or resources.

In conclusion, the features of the setting greatly impact the cyclist in the given essay. The changing terrain, scarcity of water sources, and abandoned buildings all contribute to the physical and psychological challenges faced by the cyclist. The setting's desolate nature creates a sense of isolation and amplifies the cyclist's struggle for survival. The essay illustrates the importance of considering and evaluating the features of a setting before accepting advice or embarking on a journey.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

message.content:
Once upon a time, in a small town nestled between towering mountains, lived a young girl named Lily. While the town flourished with vibrant colors and cheerful melodies that echoed through the alleys, Lily's days were filled with struggles and countless obstacles.

Lily was born with a rare illness that left her bedridden for most of her childhood, unable to experience the joyful adventures her peers embarked upon. Each day, her room became her universe, and the window her only connection to the outside world.

But despite her physical limitations, Lily possessed an unwavering spirit and an astonishing amount of patience. She could have easily succumbed to frustration and despair, but instead, she chose to embrace life in her unique way.

During long and lonely afternoons, Lily found solace in painting. With a brush in her hand and colors dancing before her eyes, she would dash pigments across the canvas, bringing the world outside her window to life. Animals, flowers, and landscapes emerged from her fingertips, each stroke a testament to her patience and resilience.

One sunny spring afternoon, as Lily brushed vibrant yellow strokes onto her masterpiece, she noticed a butterfly perched on the windowsill. Its delicate wings danced in the soft breeze, illuminating it with breathtaking hues of blues, oranges, and purples. The butterfly, too, seemed captivated by Lily's artwork.

Day after day, the butterfly returned, enchanting Lily with its beauty and persistence. It became her only companion, a symbol of hope and the embodiment of patience itself. With each visit, the butterfly would flutter around the room, as if whispering words of encouragement, reminding Lily that patience knows no boundaries.

One summer day, a young boy named Ethan stumbled upon Lily's window. He was a free-spirited and inquisitive child, known for his curiosity and love for exploration. Captivated by the butterfly flitting in and out, he marveled at the girl behind the glass and her masterful artwork.

Intrigued by the resilience that emanated from Lily's way of being, Ethan decided to befriend her. With the simplicity of a child's heart, he would knock on her window each day to share stories, laughter, and sometimes even

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf -- that work I abhor -- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' --Katherine Paterson, Author. Write a persuasive essay to a newspaper reflecting your vies on censorship in libraries. Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? Support your position with convincing arguments from your own experience, observations, and/or reading.

message.content:
Title: The Essential Role of Intellectual Freedom in Libraries

Introduction:
In a world where diversity of perspectives and ideas is essential for personal growth and societal progress, the act of censoring materials in libraries based on subjective offense should be vehemently opposed. It is crucial to recognize that the removal of books, music, movies, magazines, or any other form of artistic expression not only undermines the principles of intellectual freedom but also perpetuates a dangerous cycle of ignorance. This essay will argue against the practice of removing offensive materials from library shelves, emphasizing the importance of intellectual freedom, fostering critical thinking, and promoting open dialogue.

Body:

1. Intellectual Freedom:
Libraries represent our society's commitment to intellectual freedom, providing spaces where individuals can access a vast range of information, ideas, and creative expressions. By removing materials based on subjective offense, we undermine the very essence of intellectual freedom, limiting individuals' exposure to diverse perspectives and stunting intellectual growth.

2. Nurturing Critical Thinking:
Allowing offensive materials to remain on library shelves offers an opportunity for individuals, particularly young minds, to develop critical thinking skills. Exposure to challenging or uncomfortable ideas invites readers and users to evaluate, question, and form their own balanced conclusions. Shielding individuals from offensive material denies them the chance to engage in this crucial introspective process, hindering their ability to think independently.

3. Promoting Open Dialogue:
Rather than removing offensive materials, libraries should embrace them as catalysts for open dialogue and understanding. Encountering ideas that challenge our beliefs can lead to valuable conversations that promote empathy and tolerance. The censorship of offensive materials only reinforces existing biases and creates an echo chamber, shutting out diverse perspectives that society desperately needs to progress and grow.

4. Parental Guidance and Responsibility:
While it is important to address concerns regarding age-appropriate content, the responsibility to protect children from offensive materials primarily rests with parents and guardians. Libraries already incorporate various methods, such as rating systems or designated children's sections, to assist parents in making informed choices. Empowering parents to guide their children's reading choices respects their right to foster their child's values, while still preserving intellectual freedom for others.

5. Slippery Slope of Censorship:
Censorship, no matter how well

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist shop to see if the plant can be purchased. It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in seemingly random profusion. “Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy potted plant by the corner. There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1 “Saebba,” Saeng whispered. A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the bucket. Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world. When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between tiled roofs. And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it.  “Dok Malik,” she said, savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its tag, “jasmine.” One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it. Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone.And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept. It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk. As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to her. Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully. “Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind. Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where did you get it?” “I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question. “How much?” For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins. “That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .” “No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said. “Then what else—?” “Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.” “You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. “What happened?” she asked, more gently. “I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” “It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. “I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said. “I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.” She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply. “Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her. Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?” “I’d love it,” Saeng said. Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it. She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue. But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac. The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.Now read the last paragraph of the story. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.Write a response that explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. In your response, include details and examples from the story that support your ideas.

message.content:
The author concludes the story with the paragraph, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to convey the themes of hope, resilience, and the connection between our personal histories and our futures.

Throughout the story, Saeng experiences a deep sense of loss and displacement after moving to the United States from Vietnam. The familiar plant Saeng encounters at the florist shop triggers memories of her childhood in Vietnam and the close bond she shared with her grandmother. However, these memories also serve as a painful reminder of what she has left behind. Saeng's tears in the greenhouse are a manifestation of this loss, expressing the deep emotions she is grappling with.

By concluding the story with Saeng's silent vow to retake her driver's test and her anticipation of the geese returning and the hibiscus budding in the spring, the author symbolizes hope and resilience. Despite the difficulties Saeng faces, she still holds onto the belief that things will get better and that she can rebuild a sense of familiarity and belonging in her new environment. The return of the geese and the budding of the hibiscus represent cycles of nature, suggesting that life will continue and bring new opportunities.

Furthermore, the author emphasizes the connection between our personal histories and our futures. Saeng's connection to her homeland is manifested through her familiarity with the plants in the florist shop. Each plant evokes memories of her childhood in Vietnam, a world she longs to hold on to. The hibiscus plant, in particular, becomes a symbol of her past, but also of her potential for growth and transformation. By vowing to retake her driver's test when the hibiscus is budding, Saeng demonstrates her determination to reconcile her past and create a new future for herself.

Overall, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to highlight the themes of hope, resilience, and the connection between personal history and future aspirations. Saeng's silent vow encapsulates the ability to find strength in the face of adversity, the power of hope, and the potential for growth and

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

message.content:
Growing up, my grandparents' house was always filled with joy, love, and laughter. Every summer, my family would gather there for a few weeks to unwind and reconnect. It was during one of these unforgettable summers that I witnessed firsthand how laughter can strengthen the bonds between people.

On a sunny afternoon, my cousins, siblings, and I decided to organize a surprise water balloon ambush for our grandparents. Armed with dozens of colorful balloons, we eagerly worked together to fill them to the brink with cold water. We giggled mischievously, knowing that the impending prank would create a memorable moment.

As my grandparents relaxed on their porch, savoring the tranquility of the day, we quietly positioned ourselves throughout the yard, ready for our grand entrance. Upon a signal, we simultaneously launched the water balloons towards our unsuspecting targets. The balloons burst mid-air, drenching our grandparents from head to toe.

Their initial shock quickly transformed into unrestrained laughter. A sense of childlike joy washed over their faces as they embraced the unexpected shower. We stood frozen for a moment, unsure of how they would react. However, their laughter was infectious, and it echoed through the entire neighborhood.

In that instant, something magical occurred. The roles reversed, and suddenly, we were just children, mesmerized and enchanted by the harmonious sound of our grandparents' laughter. Our elders, who had always radiated wisdom and grace, were now unrestrained and carefree, their laughter bridging the gap between generations.

From that day onward, the atmosphere at my grandparents' house shifted. Laughter became an integral part of our conversations, creating an unbreakable bond among us. We embraced the silly, the humorous, and the absurd, as laughter paved the way for deeper connections and understanding.

Through laughter, we learned to celebrate life's simplest pleasures, to cherish the fleeting moments that bring us together. Countless hours were spent sharing anecdotes, jokes, and funny stories, creating a resounding laughter-filled symphony that reverberated within the walls of our family sanctuary.

As the years passed, our once youthful group began to grow older; responsibilities, distance, and life's demands took their toll. Nevertheless, whenever we reunited, the sound

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf -- that work I abhor -- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' --Katherine Paterson, Author. Write a persuasive essay to a newspaper reflecting your vies on censorship in libraries. Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? Support your position with convincing arguments from your own experience, observations, and/or reading.

message.content:
Title: The Importance of Intellectual Freedom: Defending Libraries Against Censorship

Introduction:

Censorship within libraries has long been a topic of debate, with proponents arguing that certain materials deemed offensive should be removed from shelves. However, this perspective neglects the fundamental tenets of intellectual freedom and the role libraries play in promoting knowledge, personal growth, and diversity. Katherine Paterson aptly highlights the dilemma faced by advocates of censorship - by removing offensive works, we risk depriving ourselves of the diverse and profound literature that makes our libraries invaluable. This essay will argue that while some may find certain materials objectionable, it is essential to defend the freedom of expression and resist the impulse to censor materials in libraries.

Body:

1. Upholding the Freedom of Expression:

The freedom of expression, a bedrock of democratic societies, is safeguarded through the existence of libraries. Removing offensive materials infringes upon individuals' right to freely express and share ideas, thereby stifling creativity and hindering intellectual development. Libraries serve as institutions that facilitate interaction with a wide range of ideas, allowing individuals to explore diverse thoughts and experiences. By preserving a variety of viewpoints, even those that might be offensive, libraries create an environment that encourages critical thinking and fosters the growth of society as a whole.

2. Empowering Critical Thinking and Personal Growth:

Exposure to diverse perspectives, even those that may initially be disagreeable, fosters critical thinking and personal growth. Literature acts as a mirror, allowing individuals to reflect upon their own beliefs, question societal norms, and broaden their understanding of the world. Removing offensive materials inhibits individuals from grappling with challenging ideas and hampers their ability to form their own informed opinions. Through access to diverse materials, libraries empower individuals to think independently and develop intellectual resilience.

3. Safeguarding Against Unchecked Power:

Censorship in libraries poses a significant risk of enabling an undue concentration of power. Granting certain individuals the authority to determine what is offensive and what should be removed from shelves opens the door to abuses of power, cultural erasure, and stifling creativity. History is replete with examples where censorship was employed to silence valuable voices, perpetuating ignorance and conformity. By maintaining a commitment to intellectual freedom, libraries protect

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: More and more people use computers, but not everyone agrees that this benefits society. Those who support advances in technology believe that computers have a positive effect on people. They teach hand-eye coordination, give people the ability to learn about faraway places and people, and even allow people to talk online with other people. Others have different ideas. Some experts are concerned that people are spending too much time on their computers and less time exercising, enjoying nature, and interacting with family and friends. Write a letter to your local newspaper in which you state your opinion on the effects computers have on people. Persuade the readers to agree with you.

message.content:
Dear Editor,

I am writing to express my opinion on the effects that computers have on people, and to persuade the readers to agree with my viewpoint. It is evident that the increasing use of computers in our society has both positive and negative implications. While some argue that computers have numerous benefits such as enhancing hand-eye coordination, facilitating learning about distant places and cultures, and enabling online communication, it is important to recognize that excessive computer usage may hinder other crucial aspects of life.

Undoubtedly, computers have contributed positively towards the development of hand-eye coordination. Whether it involves playing video games or working on artistic projects with design software, the use of computers can improve one's ability to coordinate their hand movements with visual stimuli. This can enhance motor skills and spatial awareness, providing individuals with a valuable skill set.

Additionally, computers have opened up new opportunities for people to learn about faraway places and diverse cultures. With just a few clicks, individuals can access a wealth of information that was previously inaccessible. This virtual exploration allows for a greater understanding and appreciation of our global community. Furthermore, online communication has undoubtedly revolutionized the way people interact. Social media platforms, messaging applications, and video conferencing have bridged the gaps between people across time zones, providing an avenue for connecting with others regardless of geographical boundaries.

However, it is essential to acknowledge the concerns raised by experts regarding the excessive use of computers and its potential consequences. Many individuals become engrossed in the virtual world, spending countless hours on their computers, neglecting physical activities, natural surroundings, and meaningful face-to-face interactions. This digital dependency often leads to a sedentary lifestyle, contributing to the growing health issues such as obesity and related cardiovascular problems. Moreover, excessive reliance on computers may compromise real connections with family and friends, as individuals prioritize virtual interactions over spending quality time with their loved ones.

In conclusion, while computers undeniably offer numerous benefits to society, it is crucial to strike a balance between its usage and other important aspects of life. It is essential to encourage individuals to moderate their screen time and prioritize physical activities, enjoying nature, and fostering meaningful relationships. By doing so, we can harness the advantages of technology while preserving the fundamental values of our society.

Sincerely,

[Your

Those who support advances in technology believe that computers have a positive effect on people. They teach hand-eye coordination, give people the ability to learn about faraway places and people, and even allow people to talk online with other people. Others have different ideas. Some experts are concerned that people are spending too much time on their computers and less time exercising, enjoying nature, and interacting with family and friends. Write a letter to your local newspaper in which you state your opinion on the effects computers have on people. Persuade the readers to agree with you.

message.content:
Dear Editor,

I am writing to express my opinion on the effects that computers have on people in our society. While it is true that advances in technology, particularly computers, have brought about numerous benefits, I believe that their overall impact on the wellbeing of individuals and our communities is far from positive. 

Firstly, I acknowledge that computers do have their merits. They undoubtedly play a significant role in teaching hand-eye coordination, particularly in the younger generation. Moreover, they offer us the ability to learn about distant places and people, bridging geographical barriers and fostering global interconnectedness. Additionally, computers provide a platform for online communication, allowing us to connect and engage with individuals from diverse backgrounds and cultures. However, we must not overlook the detrimental consequences that excessive computer use has on people's lives and society as a whole.

One of the major concerns is the sedentary lifestyle that computers encourage. People are spending increasing amounts of time glued to their screens, neglecting the importance of physical exercise. This lack of activity can have severe implications for our health, contributing to the rise of obesity, diabetes, and other lifestyle-related diseases. Moreover, the excessive screen time detracts individuals from appreciating and enjoying the natural world. It discourages them from going outdoors, exploring nature, and engaging in outdoor activities that are crucial for maintaining a balanced and healthy lifestyle.

In addition to the physical consequences, the excessive use of computers also hampers interpersonal relationships. As people become engrossed in their virtual interactions, they often neglect the importance of face-to-face communication with family and friends. Genuine human connection is crucial for our emotional wellbeing and the overall cohesion of our communities. By substituting real-life interactions with virtual ones, we risk eroding the bonds that hold us together and compromising the support systems that are essential for a thriving society.

Ultimately, the negative impact of excessive computer use outweighs the benefits that they provide. While computers can foster certain skills and enable connections, they should be used judiciously and in moderation. It is imperative that we strike a balance between the virtual world and the real world, maintaining a healthy equilibrium that allows us to enjoy the benefits of technology without sacrificing our physical and emotional wellbeing.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It's not that a group of old guys doesn't know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place. Things change. At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn't have done was let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park. They'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn't cool down. It didn't matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so cruel. I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my sirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I'd be fine.Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch's Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head. That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain. I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. With any luck I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time. Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me. GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE'RE YOUR BEST BET! And the only bet,” I remember thinking. As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even though I didn't own a rod or reel. An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. “Where you headed in such a hurry?” “Yosemite,” I whispered. “Know the best way to get there?” I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group I'd listened to in Lodi. “Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” And I promised myself right then that I'd always stick to it in the future. Now write a response that explains how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. In your response, include examples from the essay that support your conclusion.

message.content:
In the essay, the cyclist's journey through the setting of the California high desert greatly affects their experience. The harsh and desolate environment, marked by ghost towns and abandoned buildings, creates a sense of isolation and desperation for the cyclist. The lack of resources and the changing terrain intensify their physical and mental challenges, leading to a profound impact on their well-being.

The setting's impact on the cyclist is evident through various examples in the essay. Firstly, the lack of accessible water sources in the desert creates a critical situation for the protagonist. When they reach a pump, the water is unfit for consumption, leaving them dehydrated and struggling to continue their journey. This lack of water not only affects their physical capabilities but also contributes to their mental state, as they contemplate the possibility of heatstroke and death.

Furthermore, the ever-changing terrain adds another layer of difficulty for the cyclist. Initially, the protagonist encounters flat roads, but as they progress, the terrain becomes hilly and challenging to navigate. This change in terrain causes exhaustion and a sense of hopelessness, as the cyclist realizes they are far from their destination with limited resources. The essay highlights the moment when the cyclist encounters a large snake on the road, which reinforces the dangerous and unpredictable nature of their surroundings.

The presence of abandoned towns and buildings further intensifies the cyclist's experience. The essay describes these places as ghost towns, emphasizing their isolation and decay. The protagonist encounters an abandoned Grape Juice factory, which serves as a metaphor for shattered dreams and unfulfilled hopes. These desolate environments contribute to the cyclist's feelings of despair and reinforce the idea that their reliance on advice from the old men has led them astray.

Overall, the features of the setting in the essay significantly impact the cyclist. The lack of accessible water, the changing terrain, and the presence of abandoned locations create a sense of isolation, desperation, and physical exhaustion for the protagonist. These elements demonstrate the importance of considering the environment when embarking on any journey, as it can greatly influence one's experience and well-being.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

message.content:
During my last year of high school, I had the pleasure of going on a school camping trip with a group of close friends. This adventure allowed us to escape the demanding academic routine and enjoy some quality time together. Little did I know that this trip would present us with a hilarious incident that would forever be etched in our memories.

We had spent the day hiking through scenic trails, immersing ourselves in nature's beauty. As evening approached, we gathered around the campfire to share stories, roast marshmallows, and engage in lighthearted banter. Our laughter echoed through the serene surroundings, creating an atmosphere of pure joy and camaraderie.

Amidst the laughter and playful teasing, an unexpected turn of events unfolded. Emily, a friend known for her knack for physical comedy, decided to imitate a squirrel scampering up a nearby tree. As she exaggeratedly mimicked the squirrel's movements, her hands and feet frantically scrambled as if she was climbing. We watched in awe as she effortlessly recreated the agility and agility of this woodland creature.

Suddenly, the unexpected happened. Emily, encapsulated in the role, slipped on a loose patch of leaves, losing her balance, and tumbling headfirst into an enormous pile of dried leaves and twigs. We gasped in shock, fearing she might have injured herself. But as we quickly realized she was fine, our concern gave way to an eruption of laughter that resounded throughout the night.

Emily's fall seemed like something straight out of a slapstick comedy routine. Leaves clung to her hair, and her face peeked out from the mound of foliage with an expression of mock embarrassment. Unable to contain our amusement, we burst into uncontrollable laughter, pointing and cheering at her comical misfortune.

As Emily climbed out of the pile, brushing off the leaves and trying her best to regain her dignity, laughter filled the air. We laughed not just at her fall but at the audacity of her performance, the irony of the situation, and the shared sense of camaraderie that this incident had created amongst us. Our laughter became a unifying force, strengthening our bond and highlighting the joy and vulnerability we experienced together.

From that night on,

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist shop to see if the plant can be purchased. It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in seemingly random profusion. “Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy potted plant by the corner. There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1 “Saebba,” Saeng whispered. A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the bucket. Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world. When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between tiled roofs. And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it.  “Dok Malik,” she said, savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its tag, “jasmine.” One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it. Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone.And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept. It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk. As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to her. Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully. “Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind. Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where did you get it?” “I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question. “How much?” For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins. “That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .” “No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said. “Then what else—?” “Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.” “You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. “What happened?” she asked, more gently. “I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” “It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. “I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said. “I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.” She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply. “Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her. Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?” “I’d love it,” Saeng said. Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it. She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue. But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac. The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.Now read the last paragraph of the story. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.Write a response that explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. In your response, include details and examples from the story that support your ideas.

message.content:
The author concludes the story with the paragraph to symbolize Saeng's personal growth and resilience. Throughout the story, Saeng grapples with a sense of loss and longing for her homeland in Vietnam. Seeing the familiar plant at the florist shop triggers a wave of nostalgia and reminds her of her grandmother and the traditions she left behind.

As Saeng interacts with the plants at the florist shop, she is transported back to her childhood world filled with greenery and natural beauty. The plants remind her of the familiar sights, scents, and memories she had in Vietnam. The author describes the plants in vivid detail, emphasizing their importance in Saeng's emotional journey and connection to her roots.

Furthermore, when Saeng brings home the hibiscus plant and plants it in the garden, it symbolizes her acceptance and adaptation to her new home in the United States. Initially, Saeng is skeptical of the "winter hibiscus" because it is different from the hibiscus she knew in Vietnam. However, her mother reassures her that what matters is its strength to survive in the cold months, highlighting the resilience and adaptability that Saeng must also possess.

The paragraph's mention of the geese returning in the spring further symbolizes renewal and the cyclical nature of life. As the geese return and the hibiscus buds, it suggests that Saeng's emotional wounds will heal with time, and she will be ready to face her challenges again. By vowing to retake the driver's test, Saeng demonstrates her determination to overcome her failures and regain her sense of agency and control. It signifies her progress in embracing her new life and finding a sense of belonging in her adopted country.

Overall, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to showcase Saeng's growth, resilience, and her willingness to embrace her new life in the United States while still honoring her heritage. The continued presence of the hibiscus and the geese returning symbolize the possibility of finding beauty and familiarity in unfamiliar places and the potential for renewal and growth in the face of adversity.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf -- that work I abhor -- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' --Katherine Paterson, Author. Write a persuasive essay to a newspaper reflecting your vies on censorship in libraries. Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? Support your position with convincing arguments from your own experience, observations, and/or reading.

message.content:
Title: The Vitality of Intellectual Freedom: A Case Against Censorship in Libraries

Introduction:
In our society, the presence of offensive or controversial materials is inevitable. As Katherine Paterson astutely points out, the removal of any single work that we find objectionable from library shelves would ultimately lead to a void of knowledge and ideas. Thus, I firmly believe that censoring certain materials, be it books, music, movies, magazines, or any other form of expression, is an infringement on our fundamental right to intellectual freedom. This essay aims to substantiate this stance by delving into the importance of unrestricted access to information, fostering critical thinking, and preserving cultural diversity.

Body Paragraph 1: Intellectual Freedom as the Foundation of an Enlightened Society
Access to diverse perspectives and ideas inherently nurtures an enlightened society. Censorship in libraries undermines the core principle of intellectual freedom, which promotes the unbridled exchange of knowledge, contrasting viewpoints, and the pursuit of truth. Books or other materials deemed offensive by some individuals should not be removed solely due to subjective opinions, as this deprives individuals of the opportunity to engage in open discourse and form their own informed perspectives.

Body Paragraph 2: Fostering Critical Thinking and Personal Growth
The presence of potentially offensive materials in libraries fosters critical thinking and personal growth. By engaging with controversial subjects, individuals are encouraged to confront divergent ideas and challenge their own biases. Exposure to a broad spectrum of literature and information is a crucial aspect of intellectual development, promoting empathy, resilience, and the ability to analyze complex issues critically. Removing offensive materials from library shelves would hinder this growth, stifling genuine personal enlightenment.

Body Paragraph 3: Safeguarding Cultural Diversity and Historical Accuracy
Censorship in libraries endangers cultural diversity by limiting access to narratives that offer unique perspectives on history, politics, and society. Each book, however controversial, contributes to a tapestry of collective knowledge that shapes our understanding of the world. Eradicating offensive works would deny individuals the opportunity to explore diverse cultural landscapes and learn from historical mistakes. It is through such exposure that we can establish tolerance, appreciation, and an understanding of the complexities that make up our global community.

Counterargument and Rebuttal:

message.content:
Title: The Virtue of Patience

Once upon a time, in a small coastal village, nestled amidst rolling hills and serene waters, there lived a young woman named Lily. She was known throughout the village for her unwavering patience and kind-hearted nature.

Lily worked as a primary school teacher and had a profound love for her students. She firmly believed in the power of education and aimed to nurture young minds to reach their full potential. One day, a new student named Ethan joined her class. Ethan was a reserved and introverted child, struggling with the demanding academical curriculum.

Initially, Lily was concerned about Ethan's progress, noticing the difficulty he faced with grasping new concepts and keeping up with the class. However, she instinctively knew that patience and understanding would be key to unlocking Ethan's potential. Determined, she embarked on a journey to help him thrive.

Lily spent countless hours after school, tirelessly working with Ethan to break down complex subjects into manageable pieces. She employed creative teaching methods, using visual aids, interactive games, and personalized attention. Despite encountering numerous setbacks and Ethan's occasional frustration, she remained calm and composed, never questioning his abilities.

Witnessing Lily's unwavering patience, Ethan began to feel a sense of comfort and trust. With each passing day, he gained confidence and started to actively participate in class discussions. Lily's gentle approach provided him with an environment where mistakes were seen as stepping stones rather than failures.

One sunny day, during a science experiment, Ethan accidentally spilled a solution all over his notebook, ruining hours of his hard work. Lily noticed the disappointment etched on his face but instead of reprimanding him, she offered a reassuring smile and helped him begin again. In that moment, Ethan realized the true power of patience. He realized that even in moments of frustration, there was always room for growth and support.

Over time, Ethan's academic performance improved significantly. He evolved into an inquisitive and enthusiastic learner. Lily's persistence and unwavering belief in him molded him into a resilient child with an appetite for knowledge. She had unknowingly become the catalyst that would shape the course of his entire educational journey.

Lily's story of patience did not end there
