message.content:
One summer, my family and I embarked on a memorable road trip to visit my grandparents who lived several states away. It had been years since we last saw them, so we were all incredibly excited for this long-awaited family reunion. Little did we know that this trip would be filled with hilarious moments that would forever solidify our bond through laughter.

On the second day of our road trip, after hours of driving, we decided to make a pit stop at a quaint little diner off the beaten path. The diner had that classic Americana vibe, complete with red vinyl booths and jukeboxes playing old tunes in the background. As we settled into our booth, my younger brother, Max, couldn't contain his curiosity about the ancient jukebox stationed next to us.

While we waited for our food, Max began fiddling with the jukebox, eagerly pressing buttons and rifling through the worn-out song selections. Suddenly, with an innocent smile on his face, he managed to choose the loudest and most cliché song from the 50s: Elvis Presley's "Jailhouse Rock." The moment the first chords blasted through the diner, every head in the establishment swiveled to our booth.

My family's initial reaction was a mix of bewilderment and panic, but soon enough, the contagious beat of the music worked its magic. We all burst into laughter, realizing the absurdity of the situation. Seated at our corner booth, we transformed into our own little dance floor, swaying and bopping to the rhythm of the vintage tune.

With each passing second, the awkward gazes from other patrons transformed into smiles and chuckles. Soon, people from different tables started joining our intimate impromptu dance party, leaving their worries aside and embracing the joyous moment. The diner transformed into a lively dance hall, filled with laughter, clapping, and an unexpected sense of camaraderie.

As the last chorus of the song played, we reluctantly returned to our booth, catching our breath from an uproarious dance session that none of us expected. The lingering laughter and shared experience created an indescribable closeness among us.

For the rest of our road trip, the memory of that diner

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It's not that a group of old guys doesn't know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place. Things change. At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn't have done was let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park. They'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn't cool down. It didn't matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so cruel. I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my sirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I'd be fine.Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch's Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head. That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain. I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. With any luck I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time. Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me. GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE'RE YOUR BEST BET! And the only bet,” I remember thinking. As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even though I didn't own a rod or reel. An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. “Where you headed in such a hurry?” “Yosemite,” I whispered. “Know the best way to get there?” I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group I'd listened to in Lodi. “Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” And I promised myself right then that I'd always stick to it in the future. Now write a response that explains how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. In your response, include examples from the essay that support your conclusion.

message.content:
In the essay, "Never Take Travel Advice from Old-Timers," the features of the setting—the desolate roads, lack of resources, and unreliable landmarks—affect the cyclist both physically and emotionally. These features contribute to the cyclist's struggle with dehydration, exhaustion, and a sense of despair.

Firstly, the desolate roads of the setting play a crucial role in the cyclist's journey. The author describes riding through a ghost town where civilization seems to have vanished. The lack of functioning water pumps and scarcity of resources, such as drinkable water, adds to the cyclist's physical and mental burdens. For example, when the cyclist encountered the rusty water pump, they struggled to extract any usable water, which had the taste of battery acid. This portrays the harsh reality of the setting and the cyclist's desperate need for hydration.

Secondly, the unreliable landmarks highlight the cyclist's vulnerability and dependence on others for guidance. The old men's advice leads the cyclist astray, causing a longer and more treacherous journey. Despite their wisdom, the old men were disconnected from the changing world and unaware of the arduous conditions the cyclist would face. As a result, the cyclist is forced to navigate unfamiliar terrains, encounter dangerous wildlife, and endure extreme temperatures. This shows how the cyclist's trust in the wrong advice amplified their struggles and put them in life-threatening situations.

Lastly, the emotional impact of the setting is evident in the cyclist's thoughts and feelings. The isolation and absence of any signs of civilization contribute to a sense of hopelessness and despair. The imagery of the abandoned Welch's Grape Juice factory serves as a metaphor for shattered dreams and lost expectations. The cyclist contemplates their own mortality and acknowledges the irony of their situation. The setting intensifies the emotional weight of the cyclist's journey, adding depth to their internal struggle and determination to survive.

In conclusion, the features of the setting, including desolate roads, lack of resources, and unreliable landmarks, significantly impact the cyclist both physically and emotionally. The challenging conditions exacerbate the cyclist's battle with dehydration and exhaustion, while also causing feelings of despair and vulnerability. The essay underscores the importance of considering the setting when embarking upon a journey, as it can have a profound influence

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living for a year in a furnished one-room apartment, twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria and twenty-seven-year-old Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon call home.In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home.Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that “family” had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need.Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and first friend), lived above us, and Alegria graced our kitchen table for meals more often than not. Also at the table were Sergio and Edelmira, my surrogate grandparents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not know my “real” grandparents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, until 1970 when they were allowed to leave Cuba.) My aunts Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria, and Rosemary also all lived nearby and regularly joined us at our table. Countless extended family members came and went — and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us.My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships. The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved. In Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times. I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I’ve often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I’ve often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I’ve thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life.It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of “family.” And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home.Now describe the mood created by the author in the memoir. Support your answer with relevant and specific information from the memoir.

message.content: The author creates a warm and nostalgic mood in this memoir. The use of specific details and sensory imagery, such as the aromas of the kitchen and the sounds of Cuban music, evoke a sense of comfort and fondness for the author's childhood home. The author also emphasizes the strong sense of community and solidarity in their neighborhood, describing how different cultures came together and extended a helping hand to one another. This highlights the theme of family and the importance of relationships in the author's life. Additionally, the author expresses gratitude and admiration for their parents' sacrifices, emphasizing the love and sacrifice that they demonstrated. Overall, the memoir conveys a mood of love, gratitude, and a deep appreciation for the simple joys of family and home.

message.content:
In this memoir, the author creates a warm and nostalgic mood. They paint a vivid picture of their childhood home and the nurturing environment that their parents created. The author emphasizes the importance of family, both biological and chosen, and describes the close-knit community in which they grew up.

The author uses descriptive language to evoke a sense of warmth and comfort. They mention the aromas of the kitchen, the passion of Cuban music, and the endless celebrations that filled their home. These details create a sensory experience for the reader and contribute to the overall mood of warmth and nostalgia.

The author also highlights the generosity and selflessness of their parents and community. They describe how their parents took in temporary guests and welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival in the country. This demonstrates the spirit of generosity and solidarity that was present in their neighborhood. It contributes to the positive and uplifting mood of the memoir.

Furthermore, the author expresses profound gratitude towards their parents and acknowledges the sacrifices they made to provide a better life for their children. This gratitude, along with their admiration for their parents' strength and perseverance, adds an element of appreciation and reverence to the mood of the memoir.

Overall, the author creates a mood of warmth, nostalgia, and gratitude in their memoir. The depiction of their childhood home, the emphasis on family and community, and the expression of gratitude contribute to this mood.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: When the Empire State Building was conceived, it was planned as the world’s tallest building, taller even than the new Chrysler Building that was being constructed at Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue in New York. At seventy-seven stories, it was the tallest building before the Empire State began construction, and Al Smith was determined to outstrip it in height. The architect building the Chrysler Building, however, had a trick up his sleeve. He secretly constructed a 185-foot spire inside the building, and then shocked the public and the media by hoisting it up to the top of the Chrysler Building, bringing it to a height of 1,046 feet, 46 feet taller than the originally announced height of the Empire State Building. Al Smith realized that he was close to losing the title of world’s tallest building, and on December 11, 1929, he announced that the Empire State would now reach the height of 1,250 feet. He would add a top or a hat to the building that would be even more distinctive than any other building in the city. John Tauranac describes the plan: [The top of the Empire State Building] would be more than ornamental, more than a spire or dome or a pyramid put there to add a desired few feet to the height of the building or to mask something as mundane as a water tank. Their top, they said, would serve a higher calling. The Empire State Building would be equipped for an age of transportation that was then only the dream of aviation pioneers. This dream of the aviation pioneers was travel by dirigible, or zeppelin, and the Empire State Building was going to have a mooring mast at its top for docking these new airships, which would accommodate passengers on already existing transatlantic routes and new routes that were yet to come. The Age of Dirigibles By the 1920s, dirigibles were being hailed as the transportation of the future. Also known today as blimps, dirigibles were actually enormous steel-framed balloons, with envelopes of cotton fabric filled with hydrogen and helium to make them lighter than air. Unlike a balloon, a dirigible could be maneuvered by the use of propellers and rudders, and passengers could ride in the gondola, or enclosed compartment, under the balloon. Dirigibles had a top speed of eighty miles per hour, and they could cruise at seventy miles per hour for thousands of miles without needing refueling. Some were as long as one thousand feet, the same length as four blocks in New York City. The one obstacle to their expanded use in New York City was the lack of a suitable landing area. Al Smith saw an opportunity for his Empire State Building: A mooring mast added to the top of the building would allow dirigibles to anchor there for several hours for refueling or service, and to let passengers off and on. Dirigibles were docked by means of an electric winch, which hauled in a line from the front of the ship and then tied it to a mast. The body of the dirigible could swing in the breeze, and yet passengers could safely get on and off the dirigible by walking down a gangplank to an open observation platform. The architects and engineers of the Empire State Building consulted with experts, taking tours of the equipment and mooring operations at the U.S. Naval Air Station in Lakehurst, New Jersey. The navy was the leader in the research and development of dirigibles in the United States. The navy even offered its dirigible, the Los Angeles, to be used in testing the mast. The architects also met with the president of a recently formed airship transport company that planned to offer dirigible service across the Pacific Ocean. When asked about the mooring mast, Al Smith commented: [It’s] on the level, all right. No kidding. We’re working on the thing now. One set of engineers here in New York is trying to dope out a practical, workable arrangement and the Government people in Washington are figuring on some safe way of mooring airships to this mast. Designing the Mast The architects could not simply drop a mooring mast on top of the Empire State Building’s flat roof. A thousand-foot dirigible moored at the top of the building, held by a single cable tether, would add stress to the building’s frame. The stress of the dirigible’s load and the wind pressure would have to be transmitted all the way to the building’s foundation, which was nearly eleven hundred feet below. The steel frame of the Empire State Building would have to be modified and strengthened to accommodate this new situation. Over sixty thousand dollars’ worth of modifications had to be made to the building’s framework. Rather than building a utilitarian mast without any ornamentation, the architects designed a shiny glass and chrome-nickel stainless steel tower that would be illuminated from inside, with a stepped-back design that imitated the overall shape of the building itself. The rocket-shaped mast would have four wings at its corners, of shiny aluminum, and would rise to a conical roof that would house the mooring arm. The winches and control machinery for the dirigible mooring would be housed in the base of the shaft itself, which also housed elevators and stairs to bring passengers down to the eighty-sixth floor, where baggage and ticket areas would be located. The building would now be 102 floors, with a glassed-in observation area on the 101st floor and an open observation platform on the 102nd floor. This observation area was to double as the boarding area for dirigible passengers. Once the architects had designed the mooring mast and made changes to the existing plans for the building’s skeleton, construction proceeded as planned. When the building had been framed to the 85th floor, the roof had to be completed before the framing for the mooring mast could take place. The mast also had a skeleton of steel and was clad in stainless steel with glass windows. Two months after the workers celebrated framing the entire building, they were back to raise an American flag again—this time at the top of the frame for the mooring mast. The Fate of the Mast The mooring mast of the Empire State Building was destined to never fulfill its purpose, for reasons that should have been apparent before it was ever constructed. The greatest reason was one of safety: Most dirigibles from outside of the United States used hydrogen rather than helium, and hydrogen is highly flammable. When the German dirigible Hindenburg was destroyed by fire in Lakehurst, New Jersey, on May 6, 1937, the owners of the Empire State Building realized how much worse that accident could have been if it had taken place above a densely populated area such as downtown New York. The greatest obstacle to the successful use of the mooring mast was nature itself. The winds on top of the building were constantly shifting due to violent air currents. Even if the dirigible were tethered to the mooring mast, the back of the ship would swivel around and around the mooring mast. Dirigibles moored in open landing fields could be weighted down in the back with lead weights, but using these at the Empire State Building, where they would be dangling high above pedestrians on the street, was neither practical nor safe. The other practical reason why dirigibles could not moor at the Empire State Building was an existing law against airships flying too low over urban areas. This law would make it illegal for a ship to ever tie up to the building or even approach the area, although two dirigibles did attempt to reach the building before the entire idea was dropped. In December 1930, the U.S. Navy dirigible Los Angeles approached the mooring mast but could not get close enough to tie up because of forceful winds. Fearing that the wind would blow the dirigible onto the sharp spires of other buildings in the area, which would puncture the dirigible’s shell, the captain could not even take his hands off the control levers. Two weeks later, another dirigible, the Goodyear blimp Columbia, attempted a publicity stunt where it would tie up and deliver a bundle of newspapers to the Empire State Building. Because the complete dirigible mooring equipment had never been installed, a worker atop the mooring mast would have to catch the bundle of papers on a rope dangling from the blimp. The papers were delivered in this fashion, but after this stunt the idea of using the mooring mast was shelved. In February 1931, Irving Clavan of the building’s architectural office said, “The as yet unsolved problems of mooring air ships to a fixed mast at such a height made it desirable to postpone to a later date the final installation of the landing gear.” By the late 1930s, the idea of using the mooring mast for dirigibles and their passengers had quietly disappeared. Dirigibles, instead of becoming the transportation of the future, had given way to airplanes. The rooms in the Empire State Building that had been set aside for the ticketing and baggage of dirigible passengers were made over into the world’s highest soda fountain and tea garden for use by the sightseers who flocked to the observation decks. The highest open observation deck, intended for disembarking passengers, has never been open to the public.Now based on the excerpt, describe the obstacles the builders of the Empire State Building faced in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. Support your answer with relevant and specific information from the excerpt.

message.content:
The builders of the Empire State Building faced several obstacles in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. Firstly, one major obstacle was the safety concerns associated with dirigibles using hydrogen as a fuel source. The accident involving the German dirigible Hindenburg, which was destroyed by fire in 1937, highlighted the highly flammable nature of hydrogen. This posed a significant risk in a densely populated area like downtown New York, leading to apprehensions about the use of hydrogen-filled dirigibles at the Empire State Building.

Secondly, the nature of the winds on top of the building presented a challenge. The constantly shifting and violent air currents made it difficult for dirigibles to remain stable and stationary when moored to the mast. Even if tethered, the back of the dirigible would swivel around the mast, potentially causing hazardous situations. Furthermore, the use of lead weights to stabilize the dirigibles was not feasible in this urban setting, as there was a risk of them falling and endangering pedestrians below.

Additionally, existing laws against airships flying too low over urban areas posed a practical obstacle. The Empire State Building was subject to these regulations, making it illegal for dirigibles to tie up at the building or even approach the area. This legal constraint limited the possibility of utilizing the mooring mast for dirigible docking.

Overall, the safety risks associated with hydrogen-filled dirigibles, the challenges posed by the shifting winds on top of the building, and existing legal restrictions on airship operations were the main obstacles the builders of the Empire State Building faced in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there.

message.content:
In the memoir, the author successfully creates a mood of warmth, love, and gratitude. The author uses descriptive language and personal anecdotes to convey the cozy atmosphere of their childhood home and the sense of unity within their neighborhood.

Firstly, the author describes their home as a "warm home" with the kitchen being the heart of it. Through this vivid imagery, the author emphasizes the importance of the kitchen and how it symbolizes the love and togetherness that permeated their upbringing. messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It's not that a group of old guys doesn't know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place. Things change. At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn't have done was let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park. They'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn't cool down. It didn't matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so cruel. I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my sirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I'd be fine.Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch's Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head. That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain. I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. With any luck I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time. Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me. GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE'RE YOUR BEST BET! And the only bet,” I remember thinking. As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even though I didn't own a rod or reel. An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. “Where you headed in such a hurry?” “Yosemite,” I whispered. “Know the best way to get there?” I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group I'd listened to in Lodi. “Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” And I promised myself right then that I'd always stick to it in the future. message.content:
The features of the setting in the essay greatly affect the cyclist both physically and mentally. The cyclist's journey takes place in the high deserts of California, a harsh and unforgiving environment. The scorching sun and lack of water sources create a constant struggle for the cyclist, leading to physical exhaustion and dehydration. Additionally, the desolate and isolated nature of the setting amplifies the cyclist's sense of vulnerability and hopelessness.

One example of how the setting affects the cyclist is the lack of reliable water sources. The essay describes the cyclist's desperate attempt to find water at a rusted water pump, only to be met with brackish water that tastes like battery acid. This not only adds to the physical challenges of the journey by exacerbating the cyclist's dehydration, but also highlights the unpredictability of the setting. The cyclist's reliance on the advice of the old men leads him to a situation where he is unable to find the necessary resources, further emphasizing the harshness of the environment.

Furthermore, the isolation of the setting plays a significant role in affecting the cyclist's state of mind. The essay describes the cyclist's realization that he is completely alone, with no signs of civilization in sight. This isolation intensifies the cyclist's feelings of hopelessness and despair. The abandoned Welch's Grape Juice factory serves as a symbol of shattered dreams and serves to deepen the cyclist's feelings of loneliness and insignificance. The lack of human presence also adds to the cyclist's uncertainty and confusion, as he questions whether he has taken the wrong path.

Overall, the features of the setting in the essay contribute to the physical and emotional challenges faced by the cyclist. The extreme environmental conditions and the sense of isolation create a grueling and mentally exhausting experience. The cyclist's reliance on unreliable advice and his subsequent realization of the harsh reality of the setting highlight the impact that the environment has on his journey.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

message.content:
One vivid memory that comes to mind when thinking about the role of laughter in relationships takes me back to a family trip I took with my parents and siblings to a quaint beach town. It was a much-anticipated vacation, and we were all excited to spend quality time together, away from our busy lives.

One evening, after a day filled with sun, sand, and endless laughter, we found ourselves gathered around a bonfire on the beach. As the night sky sparkled with stars and the sound of crashing waves provided a soothing background melody, we sat huddled together, toasting marshmallows and sharing stories.

At one point, my father, who has always been the joker in our family, decided to entertain us with a classic campfire song. He began singing an old tune about a fisherman who caught a fish so enormous that it pulled him into the water. The song had catchy lyrics and a silly chorus that we all started humming along with. Before we knew it, everyone had joined in, even the neighboring beachgoers who had curiously gathered around.

As the song progressed, my father's enthusiasm intensified. With exaggerated gestures and an animated voice, he enacted the desperate struggles of the fisherman, hilariously imitating his flailing attempts to escape the clutches of the massive creature. We were all in stitches, tears streaming down our faces as my father's performance became increasingly comical.

Unable to contain our laughter any longer, we erupted into fits of pure joy. It was an uncontrollable, infectious laughter that spread throughout the beach, drawing smiles from strangers and forging connections between families who, just moments ago, had been mere acquaintances.

In that moment, laughter became the glue that bound us all together. We realized that regardless of our differences, our shared sense of humor transcended societal barriers and brought us closer. The collective laughter created an atmosphere of warmth and camaraderie, fostering a temporary but powerful bond among a diverse group of people.

As the song came to an end, we gradually regained composure, wiping away tears and catching our breath. The atmosphere was forever changed. A sense of unity and kinship lingered in the air, an intangible yet palpable reminder of the tremendous impact

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist shop to see if the plant can be purchased. It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in seemingly random profusion. “Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy potted plant by the corner. There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1 “Saebba,” Saeng whispered. A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the bucket. Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world. When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between tiled roofs. And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it.  “Dok Malik,” she said, savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its tag, “jasmine.” One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it. Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone.And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept. It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk. As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to her. Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully. “Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind. Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where did you get it?” “I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question. “How much?” For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins. “That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .” “No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said. “Then what else—?” “Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.” “You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. “What happened?” she asked, more gently. “I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” “It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. “I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said. “I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.” She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply. “Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her. Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?” “I’d love it,” Saeng said. Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it. She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue. But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac. The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.Now read the last paragraph of the story. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.Write a response that explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. In your response, include details and examples from the story that support your ideas.

message.content:
The author concludes the story with the paragraph, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to convey a sense of hope and resilience in the face of adversity. Throughout the story, Saeng experiences a deep sense of loss and displacement as she navigates her new life in the United States. The familiar plants at the florist shop evoke memories of her childhood and homeland in Vietnam. However, Saeng's encounter with the hibiscus and her mother's reassurance about its ability to survive the winter symbolizes resilience and adaptation.

One example of Saeng's resilience is her decision to purchase the hibiscus despite the steep price. This act highlights her determination to hold onto a piece of her past and create a sense of familiarity in her new surroundings. Additionally, Saeng's decision to plant the hibiscus in her family's garden demonstrates her willingness to adapt and find beauty in her current situation. The planting of the hibiscus can be seen as a metaphor for Saeng's own growth and ability to find strength amidst change and difficulty.

Furthermore, Saeng's vow to retake her driver's test in the spring reflects her resilience and refusal to be defeated by her failures. The mention of the returning geese and the budding hibiscus in the spring symbolizes renewal and the opportunity for a fresh start. Saeng's decision to wait until the arrival of spring conveys her determination to give herself time to adjust and gather strength before attempting the test again.

Overall, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize Saeng's resilience, hope, and ability to navigate the challenges of her new life. The mention of spring and the promise of the geese returning and the hibiscus blooming symbolize the cyclical nature of life and the possibility for new beginnings. By ending the story on a note of hope, the author leaves the reader with a sense of optimism and the belief that Saeng will continue to overcome obstacles and find her place in this new world.

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: Read this source essay: FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It's not that a group of old guys doesn't know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place. Things change. At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn't have done was let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park. They'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn't cool down. It didn't matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so cruel. I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my sirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I'd be fine.Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch's Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head. That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain. I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. With any luck I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time. Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me. GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE'RE YOUR BEST BET! And the only bet,” I remember thinking. As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even though I didn't own a rod or reel. An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. “Where you headed in such a hurry?” “Yosemite,” I whispered. “Know the best way to get there?” I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group I'd listened to in Lodi. “Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” And I promised myself right then that I'd always stick to it in the future. Now write a response that explains how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. In your response, include examples from the essay that support your conclusion.

message.content:
The features of the setting in the essay significantly affect the cyclist's experience and decision-making. The author's decision to trust the advice of the "old-timers" and their misleading travel advice leads to a series of unfortunate events that test the cyclist's physical and mental endurance.

Firstly, the author describes the serene reservoir campground outside Lodi, California, where they initially engage in conversation with the old codgers. This peaceful and calm setting sets up a false sense of security and trust. The author, in a moment of foolishness, shares their map with the old men, allowing them to steer the cyclist in the wrong direction. The initially tranquil and enjoyable environment becomes the catalyst for the cyclist's later struggles and challenges.

The author's journey takes them through desolate and unforgiving landscapes, with abandoned ghost towns and dilapidated structures. The essay mentions a rusty water pump that produces undrinkable water, forcing the cyclist to conserve their dwindling water supply. This scarcity of vital resources intensifies the cyclist's physical and mental hardships, causing them to question their decision to trust the old men's advice.

Additionally, the essay describes the harsh terrain and challenging road conditions the cyclist encounters. The mention of a "ROUGH ROAD AHEAD" sign and the presence of tumbleweeds and a large snake symbolize the cyclist's increasing isolation and vulnerability. The grueling uphill climbs and the absence of any signs of civilization further heighten the cyclist's desperation and sense of being stranded in an inhospitable environment.

The essay also highlights the oppressively hot weather in the high deserts of California in June. The sun's scorching heat, combined with the cyclist's dehydration due to the lack of drinkable water, becomes a significant physical obstacle. The author's description of their "dehydrated state" and the realization that they could succumb to heatstroke underscores the dire consequences of relying on inaccurate advice.

Towards the end of the essay, the cyclist stumbles upon Gary and Wilber's Fish Camp, a ray of hope in an otherwise hopeless situation. The presence of a modern bathroom and access to drinkable water signifies a moment of relief and salvation for the cyclist. This final setting offers respite and a chance for the cyclist

messages.content: You will be given an essay prompt. Respond it to the best of your ability: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

message.content:
In our lives, laughter serves as a powerful tool that bridges gaps and creates unbreakable bonds. I vividly recall an experience that exemplified the profound impact of laughter within a relationship. It was during my high school years when I developed an inseparable friendship with Sam, a classmate who had recently immigrated to our country.

Sam's arrival brought a refreshing perspective to our multicultural school environment, and his limited command of the English language made us find innovative ways to communicate. Despite the language barrier, we quickly realized that laughter was a universal language that needed no translation.

One sunny afternoon, our school organized a cultural exchange event where students from different backgrounds showcased their traditional dances, music, and customs. Eager to share his own culture, Sam decided to perform a traditional dance from his homeland. Excitement filled the air as curious students gathered around the stage, eager to witness Sam's performance.

As the music started playing, Sam confidently took his place on the stage. Initially, his graceful movements seemed to align with the cultural dance we had anticipated. However, a sudden twist in the music caught Sam by surprise, and he found himself unable to synchronize his steps. Panic washed over him, but rather than becoming disheartened, Sam decided to embrace the unpredictable situation and continued his dance in a comedic fashion.

The rhythm of the music transformed into a lighthearted melody, and Sam improvised his moves, injecting humor into every gesture. His awkward but hilarious dance moves drew uncontrollable laughter from the audience, as we found ourselves caught between admiration for Sam's courage and the sheer entertainment of the situation.

Witnessing our response, Sam's initial anxiety melted away, soon replaced by a contagious joy that enveloped the entire crowd. Strangers became friends, connected by laughter in a symbiotic bond that transcended language, cultural backgrounds, and societal barriers.

From that day forward, our friendship with Sam became a living testament to the unifying power of laughter. With each passing day, we discovered new ways to communicate through humor. We would often gather during lunch breaks, perfecting our comedic timing and sharing hilarious anecdotes, acting as interpreters for Sam's humor while he perfected his English skills.

Laughter became an integral part of our
